3: Before Ray began to understand the world around him, he had already forgotten his mother's face.
From very early on, he was raised by his father and grandma.
His grandma has always lived in the shadow of hatred.
She says that the Punishing Virus has taken everything from her.
How did it exactly?
Ever since he was born into this world and opened his eyes for the first time—he did not know.
The world was already like this.
But everyone always tells him that the world should not be like this.
That machines should not attack humans. That those towering builds used to be our homes.
Mankind had spread to every corner of the Earth, conquered the highest mountain and reached the deepest trench.
We were just shy of leaving this planet and spreading our footprints across the cosmos.
We should not be like rats subsisting in the dark corners of an apocalyptic world.
However, he had never seen that bygone era. All that remains in his hands are the vestiges of the past.
Perhaps, not even that.
Should he be filled with hate? Toward whom?
People do not blame landslides, earthquakes, tsunamis, and the cruelty of nature.
When something has become a part of this world, it is no different from natural disasters. The Punishing Virus is no different.
Ray has only seen this world, so he has naturally accepted all of its cruelty.
Deep within his memory, he sees the blurry image of a woman hugging him and humming an unknown song.
—A lullaby.
At least that's what the people of the Golden Age called it.
The lyrics have been lost to time. All that remains is the melody.
It's like a gentle stream of warm and tender feelings.
That's the last sound left by his mother.
Only from that lullaby could they feel the last bit of warmth from their past.
Daddy...
...Daddy. Where are you?
Daddy, I'm scared.
Daddy...
Ray...
Hearing the familiar voice, the boy hurries in the direction of the tide.
The sound of waves is close at hand.
As if within reach.
But before the boy can get close to the river, a magnificent and loud sound masks his 'father's whispers.'
A slender female shadow looms above the Red Tide.
He stops in his tracks.
Hearing the words contained within the 'song,' the boy burst into tears.
Lee, you're back. Where's the commandant?
Gone.
What do you mean, 'gone'...? Where did the commandant go?
To search for the source of the Red Tide with the Strike Hawk.
...I can't let the commandant go alone.
And with that, she prepares to leave.
Only to be stopped by Lee.
That won't be necessary. The commandant isn't alone. The Strike Hawk is there, too.
Wanshi? That makes me feel a little better, but if it's just the two of them...
Lee, can you explain?
The commandant wouldn't just leave without a reason. I wanna know why.
Lucia, Liv, the commandant orders us to wait here.
Why? Aren't the Gray Ravens a team?
And with the commandant's current state...
The fact that Gray Ravens will always be a team is precisely why we are staying.
Lucia, you were confused once, too. I'm sure you trust the commandant's intuition.
Lucia's concern begins to subside.
Because there are things that only we can do here.
Because... everyone else is here...
Exactly. If we went with the commandant, we wouldn't be able to help if disaster strikes.
Whether that be gathering everyone together, protecting them, or buying enough time for the commandant.
Are you worried? Are you afraid of being court-martialed with the commandant?
No, of course not. I'm just worried about the commandant's safety.
But I trust the commandant's judgment.
Same here.
Let's use this time to do what the commandant wants us to do.
Chief Commander Hans.
You're... Gray Raven?
Correct. I'm the Gray Raven's technical support Construct.
If you have any issues, speak with your commandant instead of reporting directly to me.
I hope the Gray Raven Commandant taught you all proper chain of command.
I know the proper 'chain of command,' but special circumstances have left our commandant indisposed.
Indisposed? What do you mean?
The commandant has already left.
Come again?
The commandant has already left to find a child named Ray.
When did the commandant leave?
Not too long ago. I disassembled the functional part of our bit domain node and gave it to the commandant to be deployed.
(Scoffs)
If I understand you correctly, the Gray Raven Commandant is blatantly violating my orders, and you are an accessory to the commandant's disobedience?
I don't think seeking a solution to our current predicament is in violation of your orders, sir.
As far as I'm concerned, you only came to tell me that you are going to be court-martialed together.
No.

Chief Commander, we came here hoping that you would reconsider the strike plan in favor of a precision strike that would wipe out the Red Tide and protect the refugees without the need to relocate them.
If you have such a plan, I'm all ears.
Not yet, but I specialize in problem-solving. Chief Commander, please allow me to—
Hans forcefully interrupts Lee.
If that's the case, then quit wasting my time.
You disappoint me. I was already perfectly clear with your commandant. Either they leave or die. There is no third option.
Your only mission is to evacuate the refugees before Babylonia activates the Longinus Arsenal. Unfortunately, your 'efforts' have yet to yield results.
A flurry of footsteps approaches, causing Lee and Hans to turn and look.
Lucia and Liv bring the refugees to the field before Hans.
Two more Constructs? Are you playing games with me, Gray Raven?
Chief Commander, I beg you to listen to what the refugees have to say.
They've already been loud and clear. They refuse to leave and want to await death.
No, that's not it, sir. They are just sad, angry, helpless and desperate.
Chief Commander, please pardon my audacity. But... have you ever been betrayed?
As a soldier, I'm sure you vehemently oppose betrayal.
No honest man tolerates betrayal.
What would you think if you and your comrades were surrounded on the battlefield and the commander ruled that sacrificing your troops was beneficial to the war effort?
I would not call it a betrayal. If sacrificing myself would lead to victory, I'd gladly die on the battlefield.
Exactly. Every soldier in Babylonia is willing to sacrifice their life for a distant victory.
That is how we are educated. That is why we understand that this is what we were born to do as soldiers.
But what about civilians? Not everyone can or must understand the meaning of a distant victory. Nor will they be willing to sacrifice their will to achieve it.
Do we not stand here to protect the free will of the people?
In the situation I just described, if your troops are protecting a group of people, and the commander orders them to be abandoned, what would you do?
Would you abandon them and allow the enemy to kill the civilians you were protecting?
Or would you order your troops to fight to the death?
Soldiers must protect civilians. However, if they can fight to protect them and choose not to, that is betrayal.
Quit trying to strawman me.
'The World Government Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act' should only apply to civilians of the World Government. In doing so, you regard them as comrades. Do you not?
Chief Commander, take a look. These are the people under your protection.
They are parents, spouses, children, and siblings. They've done nothing wrong.
But they have been met with disaster. They have only one small wish, which is to protect their home until the very end.
The commandant went to find the child out of sympathy for the child's crying grandmother. She can be saved just by reaching out with a helping hand.
Enough. Give it a rest. You've already wasted enough of my time as is.
This isn't the first time I've been in this situation. I've witnessed countless people during the Great Evacuation beyond my saving.
At that time, the horizon was painted red by countless who perished. The only chance of survival was up.

The laws of war are complex yet simple: all factors can be quantified into the addition and subtraction of effective strength. The first party to have their effective strength reduced to zero will be declared the loser.
We can think about feelings, but war will not, and neither will the Punishing Virus.
In our war against the virus, the only thing we can do is try our best to preserve our effective strength.
Some people call us hypocrites, but only those who survive are qualified to criticize hypocrisy.
You see someone crying for their children in front of you, but if you don't stop the Red Tide from entering the ocean, millions more will cry for their children.
Are you capable of protecting each and every one of them?
Do you have the ability to save everyone every time you encounter a difficult choice?
This is the first time you have been faced with such a choice. Isn't it?
And this won't be the last time. I guarantee you that.
Despite being barricaded outside by the Constructs guarding Hans—
Liv remains persistent.
This is cruelty!
Chief Commander Hans, please reconsider. Not for glory or for faith...
These meaningless deaths are unreasonable and avoidable.
Chief Commander, we are soldiers. We stand on this land in order to protect our comrades.
Whether that be the people of Babylonia or the people on Earth. We are comrades.
We shouldn't turn our weapons on those we should be protecting.
Chief Commander, did you hear what I said?
Did you say something?
We received a transmission from Team 07.
They have deployed their bit domain node.
We have deployed our node. The Red Tide's tributary is still some distance away from us.
We can't guarantee that the Red Tide won't flood the area within Babylonia's next orbital cycle.
Now is the optimal time for activating the node.
Do you want to authenticate and activate the bit domain nodes now?
Chief Commander?
Now just...
Before he could finish talking, a cry interrupts him.
...Ray ... RAY!
Behind the dunes of yellow sand, a thin figure walks toward the camp.
The woman on the verge of collapse rushes forward. After seeing the boy's face, she slaps him, kneels down in the sand, and hugs him tightly.
Noticing that the boy shows signs of corruption, Liv rushes forward, injects a serum into the boy's arm, then quietly steps aside.
The boy feels a stinging hot sensation on his face before he can even process what has happened.
Sorry... Granny.
I was just so scared... I wanted to find Daddy.
Ray, your daddy...
...I found him.
The woman just takes this as the boy's overactive imagination after being frightened.
Really? Where did you find him?
But so what? Now that it is over, there is no need to correct or shatter the boy's dream.
Yeah. He was in that r-red water.
I heard Daddy.
What'd he say?
He said—
'Take care and live a long life.'
The woman's eyes open widely.
She instantly recalls a memory long ago.
Before all of the tragedies, the newborn child rests in her arms, so fragile but so full of hope.
She kisses her baby on the forehead, then says the same thing to him.
It all seemed like just yesterday.
(Sobs)
She turns to face the Constructs of the calibration team.
No resentment, no hatred—she had exhausted all her emotions. Her voice was hoarse from crying, like a mother bear that had lost her cub.
Standing off to the side, Liv instantly understood the reproach within her eyes without uttering a word.
—Why didn't you come sooner?
At that moment, Liv gets choked up with an overwhelming sense of guilt and empathy.
Why didn't we come sooner?
If we just came here earlier... just a little bit earlier...
If only I had come here sooner...
If only I was a bit stronger...
If only I could bear some of their agony...
Would I have been able to prevent this from happening?
But how much earlier?
A few days? Weeks? Years? Before the the Acadia Evacuation? Or before the ensuing collapse and chaos of society?
No one has an answer to this question.
No one can answer this question.
